citation.article-title: Methanohalophilus mahii gen. nov., sp. nov., a methylotrophic halophilic methanogen.

p.s: Methanohalophilus (Me. tha. no. ha. lo. phiâ€™lus. M. L. n. methanum methane; Gr. n. halo salt; Gr. no. philos lover; M. L. n. Methanohalophilus methane-producing salt lover)
Members of this genus are nonsporeforming, nonmotile, irregular cocci which stain gram negative and occur singly or in small clumps.
Cells lyse in the presence of 0.001% Triton X-100 or 0.05% sodium dodecyl sulfate and in solutions with NaCl concentrations less than 0.3 M.
Surface colonies are cream to pale yellow and circular and often appear foamy due to trapped gases.
The colonies fluoresce yellowish green under 420-nm excitation.
Growth and methanogenesis require sodium, magnesium, iron, and potassium, with the maximum response occurring at a sodium concentration between 0.5 and 2.5 M.
Methanol, methylamine, dimethylamine, and trimethylamine support growth and methane production.
No growth occurs with hydrogen-carbon dioxide, acetate, formate, methionine, choline, or betaine.
Organisms are found in anaerobic sediments with salinity levels at or above seawater concentration.
